ai-ud5.6:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-ud5.6:1.3_0: Now at that time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying in the land of the Avantis near Kurararaghara on Steep Mountain.
ai-ud5.6:1.4_0: And the layman Soṇa of the pointy ears was Mahākaccānas attendant.
ai-ud5.6:2.1_0: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,
ai-ud5.6:2.2_0: “As I understand Venerable Mahākaccāna’s teachings, it’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
ai-ud5.6:2.3_0: Why don’t I cut off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from lay life to homelessness?”
ai-ud5.6:3.1_0: Then the lay follower Soṇa went up to Mahākaccāna,
ai-ud5.6:3.1_1: after approaching and worshipping the venerable Mahākaccāna, he sat down on one side.
ai-ud5.6:3.2_0: He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to Mahākaccāna:
ai-ud5.6:4.1_0: “Just now, sir, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind:
ai-ud5.6:4.2_0: ‘As I understand Venerable Mahākaccāna’s teachings, it’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
ai-ud5.6:4.3_0: Why don’t I go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
ai-ud5.6:4.4_0: Please give me the going forth.”
ai-ud5.6:5.1_0: When this was said, Mahākaccāna said to him,
ai-ud5.6:5.2_0: “It’s hard to lead the spiritual life as long as you live, eating in one part of the day and sleeping alone.
ai-ud5.6:5.3_0: So follow the instruction of the Buddhas while remaining as a householder, and at suitable times you may eat one meal a day, sleep by yourself, and practice celibacy.”
ai-ud5.6:5.4_0: When the lay follower Soṇa’s intention to go forth, but that lay follower
ai-ud5.6:6.2_0: For a second time, Mahākaccāna said to him,
ai-ud5.6:6.3_0: “It’s hard to lead the spiritual life as long as you live, eating in one part of the day and sleeping alone.
ai-ud5.6:6.4_0: So follow the instruction of the Buddhas while remaining as a householder, and at suitable times you may eat one meal a day, sleep by yourself, and practice celibacy.”
ai-ud5.6:6.5_0: For a second time when the lay follower Soṇa Kuṭikaṇṇa had recently gone forth a second time.
ai-ud5.6:7.1_0: For a third time that lay follower was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,
ai-ud5.6:7.2_0: “As I understand Venerable Mahākaccāna’s teachings, it’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
ai-ud5.6:7.3_0: Why don’t I cut off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from lay life to homelessness?”
ai-ud5.6:7.4_0: For a third time the lay follower Soṇa went to Mahākaccāna.
ai-ud5.6:7.4_1: after approaching and worshipping the venerable Mahākaccāna, he sat down on one side.
ai-ud5.6:7.5_0: He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to Mahākaccāna:
ai-ud5.6:8.1_0: “Just now, sir, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind:
ai-ud5.6:8.2_0: ‘As I understand Venerable Mahākaccāna’s teachings, it’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
ai-ud5.6:8.3_0: Why don’t I go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
ai-ud5.6:8.4_0: Please give me the going forth.”
ai-ud5.6:9.2_0: At that time in the southern region of Avantī, there were few monks.
ai-ud5.6:9.3_0: Only after three years, with much trouble and difficulty, was Mahākaccāna able to gather a sangha of ten monks from here and there to give the full ordination to Venerable Soṇa.
ai-ud5.6:10.1_0: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,
ai-ud5.6:10.2_0: “I have not seen the Fortunate One face to face, but I have heard that
ai-ud5.6:10.3_0: ‘That Blessed One is like me and such a one like me.’
ai-ud5.6:10.4_0: If my preceptor would allow me, I could go and see that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.”
ai-ud5.6:11.1_0: When he had come out from seclusion, Soṇa approached Mahākaccāna,
ai-ud5.6:11.1_1: after approaching and worshipping the venerable Mahākaccāna, he sat down on one side.
ai-ud5.6:11.2_0: He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to Mahākaccāna:
ai-ud5.6:12.1_0: “Just now, sir, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind:
ai-ud5.6:12.2_0: ‘I have not seen the Buddha face to face, but I have heard that
ai-ud5.6:12.3_0: The Buddha is like that, and so are they like.’
ai-ud5.6:12.4_0: If my preceptor would allow me, I could go and see that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.”
ai-ud5.6:13.2_0: Please go and visit the Buddha, the perfected and fully awakened one.
ai-ud5.6:13.3_0: You will see him—pleasing to the eye and inspiring confidence; peaceful in mind and faculties; attained to the supreme subduing and calm; tamed, guarded, and restrained in his sense faculties; a great being.
ai-ud5.6:13.4_0: Having seen (him), in my name you should worship the Buddha’s feet with your head, health, and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
ai-ud5.6:13.5_0: ‘Sir, Venerable Mahākaccāna bows with his head to your feet. He asks him if you are healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.’”
ai-ud5.6:14.1_0: “Yes, sir,” replied Soṇa. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled Mahākaccāna, keeping him on his right. Then he set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, set out for Sāvatthī.
ai-ud5.6:14.2_0: Eventually he came to Sāvatthī and Jeta’s Grove. He went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.
ai-ud5.6:14.4_0: “Sir, Venerable Mahākaccāna bows with his head to your feet. He asks him if you are healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.”
ai-ud5.6:15.1_0: “I hope you’re keeping well, mendicant; I hope you’re all right. And I hope you’re having no trouble getting alms-food.”
ai-ud5.6:15.2_0: “We’re keeping well, sir; we’re all right. And I’m having no trouble getting alms-food.”
ai-ud5.6:16.1_0: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda,
ai-ud5.6:16.5_0: ‘It may be, Ānanda, if the Buddha wishes to stay in the same dwelling as Venerable Soṇa.’
ai-ud5.6:16.6_0: And he prepared a resting place for Soṇa in the Buddha’s dwelling.
ai-ud5.6:17.1_0: Then, after spending much of the night outside, the Buddha washed his feet and entered his dwelling.
ai-ud5.6:17.3_0: Rising early in the morning, the Buddha said to Soṇa,
ai-ud5.6:17.4_0: “May you be inspired to speak about the Dhamma, monk.”
ai-ud5.6:18.1_0: “Yes, sir,” replied Soṇa. He did just that.
ai-ud5.6:18.2_0: Then the Buddha rejoiced in Soṇa’s presence,
ai-ud5.6:18.3_0: “Good, mendicant! It’s good that you have learned.
ai-ud5.6:18.4_0: How long have you entered the rains residence?”
ai-ud5.6:18.6_0: “Why did it take you so long to go forth?”
ai-ud5.6:18.7_0: “For a long time, reverend Sir, I have seen the danger in sensual desires,
ai-ud5.6:18.8_0: but dwelling in the home there was obstruction, with many duties and many things to do.”
ai-ud5.6:19.1_0: Then, knowing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ai-ud5.6:20.2_0: I understood the reality without attachments.
ai-ud5.6:20.3_0: The Noble One does not delight in bad deeds,
ai-ud5.6:20.4_0: In the bad, the pure one doesn’t delight.”
ai-ud5.6:20.5_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
